answers.author: Robert Carty
answers.text:
To get critical information out about construction impacts we used old fashioned door hangers. Though we didn't use this method for power outages, these were the days when not everyone had a cell phone (there were no smart phones), you were lucky if someone had internet access/email, and social media was the library bulletin board. And that wasn't that long ago!
We never did this on a city-wide scale though. Only smaller neighborhoods where impacts were localized. You might be able to help with coverage using Neighborhood Watch block captains to rally the residents to help distribute.

answers.text:
I think you also have to keep radios in the mix.  When everything else is out, people usually can still access a radio whether they're battery-powered or wind-up.

author: Shannon Flanagan-Watson
text:
What methods have you used to get critical information out to your community during a power outage?  For example, when residents and others do not have access to the Internet, TV, mobile phones, or land lines?
Thank you in advance!
Shannon Flanagan-Watson
Arlington County, VA
title: Communications during a power outage
